Gut feel is, until the volume of starship launches reaches the safe/reliable stats everyone is comfortable with, SpaceX can capitalize on the exponentially lower cost of Dragon for getting the crew up to and down from LEO. As for Starship, well, a lunar mission will require a number of Starship launches anyway: put the Starship Lunar Lander into Lunar orbit, deliver moon-surface equipment staging, refueling tankers staging, etc. So for a lunar mission, with all that going on, why not just build all Starships NOT to take Earth Re-entry (a huge cost and use of weight), and take crew up to LEO and back in a cheap & reusable Dragon. And use a Starship lunar-commuter to go to and from the moon. So on the return journey, just power-up the Dragon already in orbit (or plugged into ISS), transfer crew, and to take them down in the Dragon capsule? Eventually, you'd have 1 Dragon mission: (a) taking a new lunar crew up, and (b) a returning crew down. HOW EFFICIENT IS THAT! Who knows? In the end it may be cheaper to use Dragon for human LEO transport than to building Starships that can sustain earth re-entry! Someone should run the numbers.

The Space Shuttle Challenger had no abort system ... the 7 astronauts were very much alive, flipping console switches, and talking among themselves during the 2.5 minute fall in the intact crew chamber ... dying as they hit the water at 25 Gs ... though some were found to have sea water in their lungs ... meaning they drowned.  The public was officially told they the crew cabin was disintegrated by the liquid hydrogen tank explosion, but it was the super sonic wind that tore apart the shuttle when it turned sideways/perpendicular to the shuttle accent trajectory.   The crew cabin was built stronger than the rest of the shuttle.   This deception was to head off criticism for not providing an abort system ... not even parachutes ... because that design afforded the shuttle the ability to get The Space Force up and running.  The Hubble could have been lifted into orbit inside a third stage rocket fuselage. At a M.I.T. presentation in the fall of 2005, Chris Kraft said regarding the use of solid rocket boosters on the space shuttle: "...What is your escape system on the shuttle? Well, on Mercury and Apollo the escape system is a solid rocket. Solid rockets have close to 100% reliability as you can get. Usually if it lights it burns and it goes. God! We've got two solid rockets on the shuttle. Why aren't THEY our escape system? Because if we can get this thing to 200,000 feet it'll fly. So, we can return to the launch site and land from 200,000 feet. Because you aren't too far down rage at 200,000 feet. God! That's a good idea. Great idea! But, the rockets HAVE TO BE 100% RELIABLE. It wasn't 100% reliable on the Challenger accident... Unfortunately I cannot account for the fallacies of man... we built the solid rockets to have 100% reliability and THEY WERE OUR 'ESCAPE ROCKET'."
Personally, I don't agree with Chris Kraft's point of view of the solid rockets being the escape system on the space shuttle. The escape rockets on Mercury and Apollo were tiny compare to the ones on the shuttle. They were not segmented, running the risk of a leak, like it did on the Challenger accident. Granted, that's not the only failure mode on a solid propellant rocket. I think solid rockets were chosen for the space shuttle because they were cheaper to develop and to recover than liquid fuel rockets.

This video, and all who have publicly said that Starship doesn't need an abort system, will look foolish after the inevitable first fatal Starship accident years or decades down the line. SpaceX has apparently diligently worked for many years to purposefully reproduce most if not all of the worst features of any number of fucked-up rockets throughout history.

No launch abort system in the case of destructive vehicle failure on ascent or on the pad, despite equivalents to that very system saving at least 2 full Soyuz crews?

Hideously complicated thermal protection system composed of thousands of fragile little tiles with an annoying tendency to fall off, and which will all need careful inspection between flights lest the failure of even a single one at any stage of flight potentially doom the entire craft on reentry?

Incredibly complex fuel/ox delivery plumbing to ~30 engines, the uncontained failure of any one of which could cause cascading failure of the rest due to how closely they are packed?

Insane landing profile where they expect a rocket carrying tens or hundreds of passengers to regularly perform a suicide burn with no options in the case of engine failure or underperformance in the seconds before landing except slamming into the ground and detonating?

At the very least an airliner can glide to a safe landing, and doesn't carry oxidizer so it burns instead of detonating upon crashing. The Starship is a great example of how corporate mottos don't translate to the real world well. "Fail fast" is fine for software, not fine when it's a fireball with 100 former astronauts inside. Even if the rocket is improved from a fatal accident the loss of public and political support is a consequence which cannot be engineered away.

Sad to think that this will all seem obvious some day decades from now.

In my opinion all space vehicles carrying human life need an escape system. Nothing is ever full proof. What if starship has a major engine malfunction? You can't exactly glide it down, we've seen how it bellie flops to destruction when it has engine problems. It doesn't even have to be engines. Could be guidance or a multitude of possibilities. At least with an escape system there is hope. Look at Russia's ms10 rocket malfunction. The astronauts were saved by the escape system that kicked in.

I appreciate that NASA wouldn't accept astronauts flying on an interplanetary mission without redundancy measures due to accountability and liability issues. The point I would highlight however is that Martians will not be government employees, nor bothered about pensions or finally remotely bothered about abort mechanisms at launch, max-q, refuelling, the transfer orbit or even the orbital insertion because we all know it's a one-way ticket to Mars...

Nasa, ESA and whoever else attempts to send manned missions to the Martian surface (or anywhere else beyond LEO) will be funded by Terran governments and become the property/investment of those authorities who would in turn require the safe return of their investments (which in this case is the crews & samples) as politicians have a finite shelf-life. Believe me I know from personal experience :)

IF the Starship I eventually board suffers a catastrophic failure at any point I'll die knowing I did so chasing a childhood dream without any regrets - Musk doesn't owe anyone a promise of certain survival in uncharted territory but he will owe us a bottle of Champaign if we make it to Olympus Mons for the sheer lunacy of this whole endeavour!

Besides on a final note - how the hell would you jettison ~100 settlers from their habitation section without basically doubling the mass of the transit stage thus the fuel tripling for orbital insertion? Your theory of Starship separating from super heavy at launch is sound (no pun intended) but once it hits max-q there's no chance of aborting - max-q is literally the PNR for anyone onboard unless the ship is able to calculate a controlled descent and even then the aerofoils might tear the hull in half trying to slow the ship down before hitting (hopefully the ocean) at an uncontrollable vector.

All that being said though, I'll take my chances without wanting diapers and a pacifier (nappies and a dummy to Brits) because I was terrified of space and the potential vacuum death possibility until I realised that I'd rather die doing something truly ground-breaking and use my brain to help blaze the trail for all the generations that follow than rot in a dusty university office thinking of what could have been ;)

As far as is Known, Starship will not go to the Moon manned. NASA will only use it as a Lunar Module returning to LEO for refueling after every mission. There are two main safety problems with the Super Heavy and Starship that I can see. The first one is the huge number of engines on the Super Heavy (28 to 32) that could create problems such as thrust instability due to engine malfunctions. The Soviet N1 failed because it had too many engines and an engine malfunction led to the rocket exploding on it's pad. The second one, involves the elongated shape of Starship, relative to it's landing base area when used as a Lunar Landing Module. The Lunar surface is not flat like a landing pad on Earth, so an elongated landing craft with a small landing base might be prone to tilting over. Of course this can be fixed by extending the landing gear to the sides in order to create a larger more stable landing base.

31:23 Actually this is not really correct, Starship when fully fueled will have a TWR ≤ 1 (with all engines including the vacuum ones), and launch abort systems usually have g forces of 7 (in Orion's case) upwards of 13 (in the case of Soyuz). So Starship using its upper stage engines is not a viable form of abort, you even mentioned that using the vacuum engines at sea level could cause catastrophic issues. This also applies in the case of using it in flight, if a Starship has to escape, not only does it have to escape from a booster that is exploding but now it also has to land with far more fuel than was intended for landing with, possibly with a TWR of ≤ 1 depending on how early the abort was and how far the ship needs to boost back from. I also do not agree with the argument "some thrust is better than no thrust in an abort scenario." Unlike Shuttle where the issues weren't realized until it was long operational, Starship is early enough in its design phase that this problem should be worked around, it should be built with a launch abort system from the very beginning and there isn't really an excuse otherwise other than just pure negligence.

So if there's a problem with one of the rs-25's or the Solid rocket boosters what would happen is the main engines cutoff the boosters are separated and so is the external tank then mini Solid rocket engines activate at the edge of the flight deck and crew area then a separate is activated at then the boosters push the crew away from the failing rocket then parachutes would open and then have a nice safe splash down in the ocean, and the whole crew area will be sealed for the abort system splash down in the ocean, and this abort system could help during re entry because the crew module would have a inflatable heat shield for a re entry abort.

Being an astronaut is a rare privilege, so if one insists on 99% safety before they’ll go, maybe find one who’ll accept 95% or 90%, or even less, and get on with exploring. As for the Space Shuttle - as originally conceived, there were many viable abort modes. It was only the compromise design with a tank and SRBs that removed them. The original design was two flying manned vehicles, one the orbiter and the other a booster, which would land back at the launch site like an airplane - under power, not gliding. Budget cuts and DoD meddling totally compromised the design. But I assure you, when the Space Shuttle was conceived, astronaut safety was again the top priority.

You do realise that a 'failure' is actually a success when designing and engineering something, right? It means that you have data to work with. The SN8 was their closest perfect launch yet. The data they get from each 'failure' pretty much means that by the time people are allowed on board, there will be no need for an abort system as every single kink will be ironed out. They're nowhere near to a '1.0' launch. Each launch is to test a certain aspect of the design and anything that they can also test during the main test is a bonus. They're collecting mathematics and physics data. Why do you think crash tests for cars are a thing? If a car has no faults during testing then there's something that they've severely missed. The same goes for anything that is designed and engineered for consumer use.

An abort/escape system provides an option that is decoupled from many potential failures of the main vehicle. There are tons of failure modes every rocket must have in principle, and that also concerns Starship. These scenarios include loss of steering/control, propellant tank rupture, fuel leaks into the engineering spaces, and most importantly: systemic failure scenarios that we don't yet know about. If Starship itself has an abort mode which performs on an automated, powered landing, that's good - but this, too, relies on Starship itself being intact and under controlled flight.

About the Komarov incident: it is not strictly true that an abort system would not have saved his life. Had there been an option to eject from the vehicle with a parachute, he would at least have had a chance. Compared to the Columbia crew, his re-entry was not inherently unsurvivable after the vehicle failed.

The question of whether abort systems are necessary is more about the value one puts on a human life vs the cost and complexity involved. There is absolutely no question that abort systems save lifes. With the renaissance of manned spaceflight hopefully well underway for the upcoming 20ies and 30ies, the number of incidents where lives would be saved will go up dramatically. We are right now making the conscious decision not to save those lives. And considering the enormous capacity of Starship, these would be staggering numbers of deaths, potentially enough to put a halt to human exploration of the solar system due to a sudden public backlash.

Would I risk a ride on Starship even if it had a 50/50 chance of blowing up on the pad, as long as it enabled me to be one of the first colonists on the Moon or Mars? Hell, yes. Would I want someone I love to do the same thing? Absolutely not.

The public was officially told they the crew cabin was disintegrated by the liquid hydrogen tank explosion, but it was the super sonic wind that tore apart the shuttle when it turned sideways/perpendicular to the shuttle accent trajectory.   The crew cabin was built stronger than the rest of the shuttle.   This deception was to head off criticism for not providing an abort system ... not even parachutes ... because that design afforded the shuttle the ability to get The Space Force up and running.  The Hubble could have been lifted into orbit inside a third stage rocket fuselage. The two catastrophic failures of the STS were not directly caused by design flaws or even technical failures, they were the failure of management and the result of (at best) bad judgement and misplaced priorities.  Challenger was entirely preventable, and had they not chosen to simply whistle past the graveyard and immediately investigated the damage to Columbia (and left the shuttle in orbit) some form of repair or rescue could have been attempted.  In the case of the "old NASA" that sort of thing was captured in the slogan "Failure is not an option", and showcased with the safe return of the Apollo 13 crew.  Somehow, by the time we got into the shuttle program that attitude had changed into "Failure is not a problem." and we lost two crews as a result.

I was a skydiver since the 1960s. Skydivers have a sense of managed risk to be ok with the sport. We have a reserve parachute that is so reliable that almost no fatalities are due to it's failure. So we don't have a 2nd reserve because it would make our rigs more complex thereby less safe. We focus on the things that we can control in mitigating risk rather than worry about the things we have no control over anyway. Most people who die skydiving today are doing a high risk landing (swoop) under an open parachute anyway. And you have to choose to do that and accept the higher risk for that decision. I would probably ride on orbital capable rocket without an abort system myself. It's a acceptable risk to reward ratio for me being 71 years old. No one gets out alive from this life anyway.😎💖😎

Lots of statistics but the bottom line is every major launch system has experienced 1-2 catastrophic failures per 200 flights.  This includes Soyuz, Space Shuttle, and Falcon 9.  Remember F9 has had two failures so far, one in flight and one on the pad.  Either one would have required an abort system for crew to survive.  Starship will have to improve reliability by at least an order of magnitude to reduce chance of  catastrophic failure to 1 in a thousand, still not very good odds.  Can it be done?  Doubtful.

The difference between 100% Saturn 5 rocket engine success and falcon 9 engine success is the numbers of launches. Statistically you can calculate which one is more reliable by assuming different failure rates and calculate the standard deviation probability that the assumption is wrong. Thus many engine successes gives a much smaller sigma standard deviation and therefor falcon 9 engines are statistically more reliable than Saturn5 enginess

Does Starship have a business case that involves hundreds of unmanned cargo flights? I doubt it. Again because it is far too big.

3:48 even if 0.5% of flights would see a benefit from a launch escape system, keep in mind that space flight in general has been safe with relatively few instances of failure requiring aborts in the first place. So I wouldn't say it is a question of benefit, it is a question of whether one should engineer an abort system into the design of a launch vehicle, and, costs aside, I think it is more so a moral question than an engineering one. If one could engineer an abort system into a vehicle, and if the goal is to return the astronauts safely to earth given any number of possible contingencies, then I think it should be included in Starship or any launch vehicle. Even if we could make systems 100% redundant and reliable, it still makes sense to have every single possible safety feature for the astronauts in place, astronauts that risk their lives in going into space. Airline pilots don't risk their lives, practically speaking. I also agree the launch abort should be a separate system.

With regards to re-entry abort.  GE developed one such system in the 1960s, called the MOOSE, which was a personal reentry device.   Weighing at 200 pounds (91 kg) and and being the size of roughly a suitcase, it would have provided an emergency re-entry device for one astronaut, who would have had to enter in a fully sealed space suit including helmet with oxygen supply. The astronaut would be surrounded by inflatable foam insulation, similar to an inflatable raft, which would double as a floation device in case of water landing, and a parachute would activate at the appropriate time  The idea was not as crazy as it sounds at first, Felix Baumgartners jump showed that high altitude jumps are definitely survivable, assuming the foam insulation worked.

What about when Apollo 13 had to re-purpose many of it's parts in order to safely get back to earth? If those parts had been deleted, then they wouldn't have made it back. I feel like there must be some creative solutions out there for adding redundancy without adding too much complexity.

The shuttle program had a one mission out of 67 ending in all aboard death, record.   That's actually better than the aircraft my grandfather worked on.  He was a mechanic in the 96th Aero Squadron.  He worked on the Breguet 14 biplanes that started out as reconnaissance aircraft but ended up as bombers in WWI.    Excluding aircraft shot down, each aircraft could expect one catastrophic failure every 30 or fewer flights resulting in the death of the pilot and crew.  This should give you an idea of the level of bravery.  Every time the pilot and crew climbed aboard they knew that there was better than one chance in 30 that the aircraft would fail either on take off or in flight or in landing that would result in their death yet they would still go.   Those weren't even the aircraft with the worst record.  Some aircraft could be expected to fail about every twenty flights and yet the pilots still took off.  Keep in mind that much of the materials used in these early aircraft was wood, leather and canvas.

I worked in manufacturing for many years.  My last manufacturing job I was a safety auditor.  As such I learned about safety ratings on equipment.  The rule of thumb is that in order to say something is rated for a specific number, it had to be able to withstand up to five times that number.  For example.  A winch could not be rated for 1000 lbs unless it had a breaking point at or above 5000 lbs.  You can't say a chair is rated for 300 lbs unless the breaking point is at or above 1500 lbs and you can't say a bolt is rated for 50 lbs unless it has a breaking point at or above 250 lbs and so on.  This is standard with all manufacturing.  So to say that something should be designed at 1.5 times the expected load or stress is a very poor substandard design and explains why NASA  had three catastrophic failures resulting in loss of human life.  No system is better than it's weakest point and NASA has a history of weak points.  Hopefully Elon Musk can safely bring us well into the 21st century when it comes to Space travel

That was excellent, you've a terrific intellectual clarity coming across that's both socially and academically welcome. I think ideally space vehicles will have not just automated but, especially where automated systems may not be appropriate or useful also pilot options for even unlikely catastrophic failures but accomplishing these throughout the envelope will take time beyond initial deployment of the vehicle type, so can never really stop being a work in progress in terms of safety. For example an automated launch pad escape system has some predictable problems with specific conditions where a manual operation would be preferable in order to avoid the kind of situations seen in Airbus disasters with pilot lockout automation that would not have occurred in a Boeing where the pilot has more immediate vehicle control in priori to completely understanding the nature of the in flight failure, where time to determine and intellectually respond to the failure through the management system as opposed to direct control simply isn't present before loss of the aircraft occurs, where even redundancies of the automated flight system giving over limited pilot control also failed due to the nature of the original system failure, operator equipment variations and crew unfamiliarity with hands on vehicle control in that type in the first place. There's been a few automation related air disasters, typically Airbus and from things as mundane as incorrect calibration of the radio altimeter or the ground crew forgot to remove a sensor cover and the safety systems killed the plane whilst cockpit voice recorders relate the screams of crew frantically trying to manipulate the controls and being overridden by the automated systems, then crash investigators wondering how on earth a pilot manages controlled flight into terrain in perfect flying conditions and visibility, without any mechanical failures of the aircraft whatsoever. Certainly far fewer direct control circumstances exist in relation to space flight beyond the realm of orbital manoeuvring however at least at the pad a fully automated escape system has already demonstrated the cost of treating crews like monkeys in space suits even if, for the most part in space flight that's what an astronaut has to be.

I realize this is an old post, but engine fires in airliners are actually fairly common, you just don't hear about them falling from the sky from it. Not many rockets can survive an engine fire in an uncontrolled way due to the pressures and the tight tolerances.  Coupled with you just turn off the engine in an airliner then deploy a fire suppression system and can (at worst case) glide back to earth hopefully with a safe landing. A rocket is efficient at going up... and down but not flying. So for manned flights you still need that abort system just in case you end up with an engine fire. Additionally, in the cases were the launch abort tower was ejected then needed to abort launch: having an integrated system that is not ejected seems to add abort capability right up to the point of final stage separation.

I think you should calculate engine reliability using baysian statistics. If you fly engine A once, and succeed, you have 100% 'reliability'. If you fly engine B 10 times and have 10 successes, you also have a 100% reliable engine, and yet we consider the second more reliable because it has more evidence of reliability. Baysian stats accounts for this as follows:

Successful flights+1 / Total Flights+2

The logic being that when you have zero launches, we assume a 50% likelyhood of success or failure (1/2). If we succeed, then we update our prior to 2/3 and if we fail, we update to 1/3.

So 1 successful launch implies a 66% probability of future success. And 10 successful launches implies a ~92% probability of future success

By definition modern space-faring rocketry is a crapshoot at all times. Even systems that were considered bulletproof have failed and caused losses of life. They are massive endeavors, with millions of pounds of material, millions of man hours, and billions of dreams riding on them. It is a tragedy when they fail and claim lives. When such a time comes where the safety department is comfortable without an abort system to allow engineering to do what it does best and find the best solution that fits the parameters, we've conquered space-faring rocketry.
To date we have merely pulled open the door to space, and stare in awe at it's wonder. One day we will walk through that door, with our heads high, into the unknown. And I'm willing to bet those who venture into that unknown will have some way to save themselves, but not one that exists or is used right now.

I work in the aircraft industry. Pretty much every commercial airplane has 3 hydraulic systems and redundant electrical buses. That costs $$ and more importantly weight. Weight is so important with rockets. The weight penalty for the perforated flaps, landing struts, extra structure and extra fuel for landing the falcon rocket is huge. It’s not inly the weight of that stuff, but the weight if all the fuel required to lift all that stuff and accelerate it with the rest of the vehicle. Then that extra weight requires more structure etc etc. It’s a snowball effect. So the savings of reusing the rocket must be huge when compared to just making a cheaper simpler lighter rocket. I would not have expected that, but I am sure SpaceX did all the math before they started making stuff.

I like the fact that they're applying the KISS principle to Starship. The less parts there are, the fewer the number of parts that could malfunction.
However, at the same time, as far as safety goes: *REDUNDANCY*. All the shuttle deaths that have occurred are because of a lackadaisical view on safety. Challenger blew up because the safety rings on one of the rocket boosters failed after a particularly cold night. NASA was aware that the safety rings could fail should the temperature fall below a certain level. Columbia blew up because NASA knew the foam took a chunk out of the wing but maintaining the mindset, "Even if we knew what needed to be done, could it be done in time? Let's let them die thinking the mission was a success." I'd rather work for a company that puts safety and redundancy systems before random chance.

In my opinion, this video tries to ease a deep-seated psychological fear of not having a "back door", an escape, if things turn dangerous. Most people think that having an abort system is safer than not having one, but it becomes clear in this video that abort systems could potentially endanger human life if not designed or operated well. It takes a very rational approach, making use of probabilities.

Even so, the psychological need for an escape is so great that I suspect airliners would get significantly more passengers and money if the aircraft and each seat had a built-in parachute. Similarly, I would guess that spaceX will get more future passengers, (which leads to more money and more design iterations and faster development,) if they give those on board something they can do to get out of a disastrous situation.

If there's a six foot passageway from the top of the fuel tanks. Through the header tanks. Through the lox tank. Right out the bottom of the spacecraft. Then weld 8 fuel baffles from the center passage to the outer skin. Remember the first stage of the Saturn v was actually 8 separate rocket fuselage connected in an octagonal fashion. These baffles inside the starship are thin steel with 2 and half inch dimpled holes 6 inches apart. Very light structures for what they're supporting. If there's the passageway. Then the nose cone could be built like a ginormous cork. With the cork inserting the length of the methane tanks. The passage below the methane tank through the lox tank would have thicker steel to compensate for the single walled construction. And the fuel plumbing of the methane tanks run through lox tank passage way.

During launch the crew climbs into the passageway and sits in hammock lawn chair deals that fold out of the wall. 8 people in a circle stacked three high 24 people. Then before launch. The passage below the capsule, lox tank passage. Which is the airlock. Pressures up to whatever pressure is needed to eject the entire nose cone up and away from harms way. At 2atmosphere pressure that would be roughly 30psi inside the lox passageway. That would provide an instaneous 488,000lb thrust to the capsule alone. So that could be too much considering the entire loaded starship is suppose to weigh in at roughly 500,000lb. Once the nose of the starship is realeased and is accelerated up and out. The nose cone passageways bottom is its own component and falls away. Exposing the astronauts inside the passageway to the outside. The chairs they sit in are attached to small 2inch web x 2inch ibeams 2ft apart running the vertical length of the nose cones passageway, with rollers. And then the astronauts simply slide out 9f the nose cone 8 at a time each with their separate chutes attached to their chairs.

The KISS principle applies here - it's not something new that Elon Musk invented - it's been around since the Lockheed Skunkworks invented it in the 1960's. But you can trace it back even futher...Albert Einstein put it as "Everything should be made as simple as possible, but no simpler." - the second part of that is key here.  If you can help the crew out of a bad situation with some careful design, then of course you should do so - but adding complexity where it's not needed is stupid.


My favorite example of false safety is those life jackets they put into airliners.   Over the entire history of passenger aviation - how many lives have they saved?   Answer is "NONE!" - even in the case where that airliner splashed down in the Hudson river - the people who DIDN'T jump off of the wing and into the water were a lot easier to rescue than the few that did.

Yes, there is no abort system in "Starship". But, if there was a catastrophic event the manned section of the vehicle could have a structural breakaway point. That combined with a parachute system could give the crew a fighting chance for survival inside the atmosphere. The Space Shuttle could have had the same thing, as in both accidents the crew cabin broke away from the main body basically intact. A slight design change could have made that a cleaner break and possibly allowed a parachute assisted landing in which the crew could have survived. Starship could be designed the same way as there will be a separate pressurized interior manned structure that will be separate from the fuel tanks and frame. I think it is something that should be looked into, at the very least. There should always be a survivable option on the remote chance of total system failure.

The benefits of more engines as opposed to just one or two comes from the application of simple math. It's the equation Force = Area * Pressure. You may have a 5 ft rocket nozzle attached to a rocket with a 20 ft diameter. That 5 foot nozzle may be engough to get the job done, but you could have 4 nozzles in that same space and since the nozzle area just increased 4 times your engines don't have to be as big or as heavy and the engine doesn't have to work as hard. That's why the Soyuz Rocket is so reliable and robust. It's bottom is covered in nozzles and now you know why.

There's another angle to this, that comes from a field with arguably even higher stakes when something fails: nuclear energy . Today's reactors use solid fuel pellets and liquid water for coolant. Problem is that the COLDEST temperature you can operate a reactor and still feasibly generate electricity is about 300° Celsius. Problem is, the water must be kept liquid even at that temperature, which forces intense pressurizing. Even after an emergency shutdown, a nuclear reactor still needs continued cooling to manage decay heat of the fission-products (the "ashes" of a nuclear "burn"). This is why nuclear power plants have so many redundant diesel-generators to run coolant-pumps after reactor-shutdown. A proposed system called a "Liquid Fluoride Thorium Reactor" (LFTR, pronounced "lifter" for short) uses fluoride salts as fuel, and is designed to use them MOLTEN in routine operation. They have to be heated to about 450° Celsius to melt but they then have 1000° Celsius of liquid range WITHOUT needing to be pressurized. In routine operation you have a frozen plug of salt that you keep frozen by blowing cold gas across a flattened section of drainpipe. If the reactor overheats or the reactor building loses power, the frozen salt plug melts, draining all the reactor's fuel into a passively-cooled drain-tank designed to stop the nuclear-fission from continuing. Now while today's reactors have 5 or 6 redundant diesel generators to power those emergency coolant pumps, remember: at Fukushima Daiichi, a tsunami knocked out ALL of those Diesel generators, and as a result, once the batteries for the emergency coolant pumps went flat, those reactors had NO workable cooling. Just about every military jet has a variety of "abort systems". Both for  safety of the pilot and those on the ground. If you have to abort often you have some work to do on your design. Abort is to give you a second chance when the unexpected happens. Also remember the impact of a failed manned flight. Post successful abort there is generally a small delay. Post fatal failure there is a delay of years in most cases. Fatal failures probably contributed to the premature ending of funding for the shuttle program (before we had a replacement in place). When public figures die it is national news. When some random kid in the city dies it doesn't even make local news often. If we valued lives equally we would already have safer cars and, probably, a fire arms ban (based on the numbers).   So it is hard to apply risk tolerance evenly when it is not even close.

Great video by Everyday Astronaut as always. However, an oversight is assuming the abort system has to save the entire Starship. It doesn’t and that’s not how any abort system has ever worked, including SpaceX’s own Dragon 2 abort system.
Doing it this way as described in the video would be like on the Falcon 9 trying to save the entire second stage rather than the Dragon 2 capsule. Instead, what should be done is have the passengers strapped in the nose cone only during ascent to orbit. Remember the full passenger section is meant for a 6 month flight to Mars so has to be much roomier, and heavier. The nose cone only, like a capsule, would weigh much less. So you would just have to scale up the abort system used on the Dragon 2.

I hate the comparison of rockets to planes, because "planes don't have abort systems"... no, they just have multiple system redundancy, the ability to glide without power, the ability to land or splash down without landing gear, emergency slides/rafts, crash seats, and lifejackets for everybody. That's not including modern military eject systems, early aviation's parachutes for each passenger, or modern light aircraft parachute systems... The analogy of a larger plane not requiring to carry a smaller plane doesn't match the circumstance either as rockets already do this due to two stages.

the solution to rocket safety isn't necessarily abort systems, but vastly improving safety requires multiple layers. This is the Swiss cheese method. This could mean a separate abort system, but can also be more redundancy and integrated safety systems.

With Starship, if the upper stage is also the abort system it needs its design modified to add more thrust (needs to be greater than 1 TWR when fully loaded) and it needs to avoid interdependencies that could cause cascading failures.

while I agree that the ultimate answer to space safety is experience, and that with enough experience we can eventually reach a point where "space travel is as safe as air travel" the truth is we aren't anywhere near that point. modern spacecraft don't operate in nearly the same regime as airliners, in fact, I would say they are closer to fighter-jets than airliners; consistently operating within the upper limits of their capabilities. and with fighter-jets, even today, abort systems are widespread and frequently save lives, not just in combat, but also in "routine" training exercises. I think mechanical abort systems are, and will continue to be, important because they don't just represent an alternative path to the safe end of the mission, they provide a fundamental shift to the end-of-mission objective. when operating a vehicle like the starship, or space shuttle, or f-16, the standard end of the mission necessarily entails the landing and recovery of the entire vehicle; this is (obviously) challenging, and there is a very large margin between success, and catastrophic failure which requires dozens to hundreds of systems work perfectly. safely landing a human, by comparison, is pretty easy: you set down a 200 lb sack of meat softly without cooking it. the launch abort system gives you a way to say "well, we cant save the big expensive vehicle, let's just save the people. so, while mechanical abort systems DO represent an increase in complexity for the few seconds that they're active, they also represent a drastic decrease in the complexity of the remaining mission: run away from the explosions, wait to float back down to earth.

Personally, I tend toward the side that says no abort system. Why?

- Fewer parts and lower total system complexity is preferable, as it will result in a more easily predictable total system, with fewer chances for unanticipated interactions leading to potential failures modes.
- Abort systems are very heavy due to the extensive necessity of duplication of systems. This greatly reduces performance margins, and can therefore in its own way actually represent a safety risk, because the mission has to go pretty much exactly as planned! You really do not want to run out of delta V to land..!
- As per the previous point, having a bigger mass budget to work with if you do not have the heavy abort system means you can add additional redundancy, or mechanical margins on particularly important parts (maybe most of the things that had a margin of 1.5, you can increase to 2.0, for instance!), thereby adding safety margin

N.B.: I do wonder if in future, whether it would be possible and at all practicable to transform each crew cabin into its own self contained capsule with a parachute (say, the capsule is small and only encompasses the crash couch/bed). They could have no propulsion or anything, keeping it simple and lower weight. The idea is that if a failure occurred during flight, there is at least SOME chance of survival. Some failure modes will not be survivable, but something has to be better than nothing, right?

Also, the Ares-I abort system was planned to be active during the SRM burn of the LV; a det cord would split the SRM case, and the abort motor was designed to have sufficient thrust to pull away from the LV even during SRM max thrust.  So, you DON'T have to "ride it out" if you're using an SRM.

There were indications that the crew of the Challenger survived the initial explosion, and that the crew cabin fell intact until impact with the ocean.  A crew-escape pod would possibly have saved the crew.

If we want safety in a rocket without abort rockets, we will need lifting bodies like the Sierra Nevada unit that can be placed at the tip of any rocket and that can land on any reasonably sized airstrip. Of course, that leaves out initial boost to the speed/altitude that allows the lifting body to...err...lift. At initial boost, there might be a rocket with enough engines to spare the loss of one or two at launch to reach that speef/altitude. The Starship and Superheavy appear to be two such rockets, but that leaves out the rest of the possible failured. So, again, reliability becomes the only answer to the problem.

If I were flying it, I would want to have myself encased in a lifting body capable of reentry and horizontal landing, but that isn't going to be possible for 100+ passengers, or is it. Anything that provides transport at a speed fast enough to create g-forces strong enough to kill is a risk to its passengers and we are certainly familiar with such risks as we ride or fly in various systems that are considered safe for public transport. Anybody who has seen a vehicle burn after a less than fatal crash knows what riding on a fuel tank means. Again, reliability with reasonable safety standards plus huge usage history are the only answers that will get most people on a particular vehicle type.

Think how many people state that they will not now fly on a 737-Max and you will have the long term answer to your question. When the FAA takes responsibility for the full recertification is my answer, but I'm not sure what others feel. I know that Boeing cannot survive the permanent grounding of all 737-Max's, so they are going to have to find a solution that is palatable to the flying masses.

Having even a small percentage of customers refusing to fly on available machinery is unacceptable to most airlines and they will seek compensation. That would put Boeing into bankruptcy and completely disrupt our modern flight system, so we had better find that answer and that answer should be instructive to SpaceX 's plans to fly 100+ passengers on point-to-point flights.

Current airplanes cannot survive any but the most minor crashes in ordinary landings. Any other crashes are almost inevitably fatal to all involved, so the only way airlines stay in business is to have a mode of transportation that is orders of magnitude safer than any other mode than trains and trains take too long for most transport further than 100 miles.

There is the standard that rocketry must closely approximate if it is to be acceptable for more than inherently risky things such as trips to the Moon/Mars/the rest of the Solar System. How that is accomplished is initially a technical problem, but in the final analysis, a social problem.

Yes, the systems should be overdesigned with multiple redundancies so that the catastrophic failure is extremely unlikely to happen AND you should have a simple, crude,  mechanical, crew ejection system with the least number of parts in case these complex systems do fail. Anyone can claim their systems are fail-proof, that is until the first accident which will take 7 lives again. Then it will be: "oh, but we didn't know about this fatal flaw, who could have envisioned this?" or "It was the perfect storm" and a bunch of other excuses. With every new technology - knowledge has limits, only folly, carelessness, complacency and stupidity know no limits. Which is why it makes perfect sense to supplement new tech with an older, real life and time tested abort systems. Another factor is that it's hardly ethical from psychological perspective to put a human into a fully automated orbital vehicle without both automatically and MANUALLY activated abort system. Air travel is much safer than space travel, and still, I believe it would make perfect sense to come up with an escape system such as detachable, parachute-equipped fuselage, or similar measure.

I have an idea that could solve pad-aborts, and in my certifiably-uneducated opinion, is the highest risk time for Starship. As you discussed in the video, with more than 30 engines, and a 99.88%(so-far, and including the early failure) reliability of the Merlin, I don't believe in-flight abort is exactly necessary. I think you explained it well with the 747/Cessna analogy, Starship will be built with redundancy which makes it the escape vehicle in the event of an aborted mission.
On to my solution: A crane* would be positioned at the launch site with a tether attached to the pod. In the event of a catastrophic failure of the booster, exploding bolts detach the pod and eject it in an intended direction. The pod swings on the tether, either at a length where it won't strike the ground, or into a pool of water. There would be a mechanism to detach the tether, perhaps with a quick-reel system to avoid hitting any control surfaces or puncturing the hull. The tether would detach presumably as soon as the engines are lit. This idea is intended to solve a problem during fueling and pressurization.
*Not a mobile crane which could be destroyed by a catastrophic booster failure. Something extremely well reinforced, built into the concrete.

If the purpose is to avoid future failures, then there is more to failure analysis than the technical elements of the device. The Challenger O-ring failure is a good example.
The Space Shuttle was "sold" to the politicians of America by giving parts of the project to contractors in the respective districts of the politicians. To get the yea vote from a senator in, say, Utah, part of the rocket had to be built by a company in Utah. This company would get lucratively paid by the federal government, and expecting this, the company would (somehow) bribe the politician to support the project.
If the solid rocket boosters had been built somewhere with access to the ocean, a long single tube could have been built and shipped by sea. But because the Shuttle needed votes from Utah, Morton-Thiokol Inc. of Utah had to build the solid rocket boosters. This meant shipping the boosters by land, and consequently, they had to be segmented. This meant using the now infamous O-ring.
So, the method of funding the Shuttle led to the failure of the rocket.

I think you're misunderstanding how reliability works. Having more parts lowers reliability only if it's a series system. In parallel systems, more parts means more reliability. It's exactly the same logic as having redundancy. It just looks different on first glance since it's not as simple as having multiple of the same stuff. But if you frame the system as if you can have the crew alive or not, abort systems serve as another part in a parallel system giving it more reliability.

The whole question is kind of pointless, because people will never be happy. If it's there and not needed, people say "Well, that was a waste of resources." but if it's not there and it is needed, people say "Wow, if only there was an abort system." If you build something to be foolproof, the universe will just throw a better fool at it. The Titanic was said to be unsinkable, yet it hit and iceberg and it sank, killing 1500 people because it didn't have enough lifeboats. The U-2 was believed to be untouchable, yet it was shot down, because it didn't have any counter measures. The Space Shuttle was promised to have a failure rate of 1 in 100.000, but by the end of the program, that figure came to rest at 1 in 68.


The specific issues that caused those disasters were addressed, sure, but that means that other issues will just pop up. The Costa Concordia and the Sewol still sank, the SR-71 that replaced the U-2 still crashed more than a few times, and you even kind of argue against yourself here with the Soyuz. It has flown thousands of times, hundreds if you just want to limit it to modernity, and they still haven't made the system foolproof as we saw just last year. The list of potential failures on something as complicated as a rocket is extremely long, and not a lot need to go wrong for the thing to end in disaster. And to then not have a back up... that's arrogant and scary.

One topic I have missed in this video: Is it even theoretically possible for Starship to have an abort system and what would be the performance costs vs. safety gains? e.g. could Starship have a pair of very strong yet short burning solid rocket motors down in the engine section just intended to work the 2 or 3 seconds needed before the Raptors on Starship are realistically fully up and running? I just tried now to search a bit and answer myself and see that answer is most likely "NO"!:-) For pad abort of a fully fueled Starship weighing about 1300 tons, you would need 2 solid rocket motors with a thrust of maybe 700 tons each, which brings us close to the performance figures of the new European SRB P120 ... which has 800 tons of thrust, but with a diameter of 3.4 meters! By needing two of these (in a vehicle that has 9 meters in diameter) there wouldn´t simply be space for the "normal" Raptors, so this way is a dead end as it seems! Fighter jets and other high performance airplanes still have ejection seats, because there's a chance they'll go to pieces at an inopportune time. That said, it's very easy to find lots of examples where ejection seats have killed people who would otherwise have been safe. This is why ejection seats are not used on airliners - they'd likely be more dangerous than nothing at all (do you want all maintenance workers to need to go through explosives training before even touching an airliner?), and the failure modes of airplanes are pretty benign. Wings don't tend to fall off airplanes, and they don't tend to come apart in midair, and as long as they don't come apart they can be brought to some semblance of a safe landing.


Rockets on the other hand have a nasty habit of coming apart in midair and given the much slimmer safety margins I think this will be the case for a very long time to come.


Also, the landing mode for Starship will be fraught with danger... anything goes wrong, everyone dies, and there's not much which could be done about it.

Engine redundancy is a shaky argument in rocketry. This not just my conjecture, but of SpaceX engineers themselves. You are effectively saying:

"In case of engine failure, we can revert to other engines as backup; *assuming the failure event of the first engine was gracious enough to not damage the surrounding engines, or the fuel piping above the cutoff valves of that engine unit.*" A layperson knows that these devices usually fail suddenly and violently.

Another angle to the same issue is that engine problems are rarely the reason why launches or other space operations fail. Neither of the two Falcon9 accidents were engine problems, neither the Shuttle accidents, or the recent Sojuz launch incident where abort vehicle was used. Out of all the different ways different probe missions by NASA and ESA have failed or suffered, none have been due to engine problems. In fact, I can't recall a single incident from past few decades where engines were to blame. Last that comes to mind is the Soviet N1 rocket, whose all 4 launch attempts failed. Incidentally, N1 could have operated with some engines missing, but the failure modes always cascaded, bringing the whole engine array down in seconds.

It's all just probability in the end. But probability has two aspects: likelihood of failure and consequence of failure. Unfortunately, much as I enjoyed this video, it really only concentrated on the first aspect - likelihood of failure.


And, as humans, we are far more affected by the second aspect - consequence of failure.


If you're playing a game on your phone, that might mean you miss your bus, the chances of missing it might be quite high - but, what's the worse that can happen? You have to wait for the next bus. Of course, if you're waiting for the last bus of the day and the consequence is a long walk home or an expensive taxi ride, you might choose to not play a game. The probability hasn't changed, but the consequences have - so you don't take the chance.


If you're considering the choice of sitting on top of a cylinder full of high explosives while they're ignited, I would suggest that you aren't likely to be interested in how reliable this has been up to date. You're much more likely to be influenced by the fact that, no matter how unlikely a failure is, you are going to be very dead.


And it really doesn't matter if the system has been 100% reliable so far, you'd still want to know that you can escape if something does go wrong. Up to the point where Challenger broke apart, the reliabilty of the Shuttle was 100%. And before Columbia, there had been no problems for 17 years. So, in both cases, the probabilty of failure was (apparently) incredibly low - but the consequence of failure was stilll exactly the same - certain death, as there was no abort system.

Well, if it has not been demonstrated that launch abort systems have been significantly useful for saving people, then no they are not needed. You don't want to add anything you do not need as it just becomes one more thing that can kill everyone if it fails.


As you said, simply launch the vehicle unmanned multiple times to certify its safety before putting crew onboard.

I think that your closing logic is flawed in the argument about "...the simplicity of a design that doesn't have all those extra parts and just focus on making [the rocket] more reliable." That kind of assumes that there is a fixed constraint on resources (time, people and money) and that diverting some resources into making an abort system means taking away resources that would otherwise be able to make the rocket more reliable. It could be argued that in a case like SpaceX which is a "for profit" company, that yes, there is always a constraint on resources, but do we really know that if Elon wanted there to be an abort system, that he would take resources away from other aspects of the rocket design and therefore would end up with a less reliable rocket, or would he dedicate a new team to the abort system and pay for that by increasing the price of the launches? In other words, I don't agree that having an abort system means you must have a less reliable rocket (when referring to the rest of the rocket.)


However I admit that having an abort system does equate to increasing parts, complexity and potential modes of failure. From that perspective, it could decrease overall system reliablity, but if it works more often that it fails (and hopefully a lot more often than it fails), then having it could increase the safety of the crew. This is compared to an otherwise identically reliable rocket that doesn't have an abort system.

My take away from this video is that some of the things the starship will do are inherently risky (37 engines, propulsive reentry), but there are some failsafes the shuttle didn't have.  I think you're ignoring the fact that many of these failsafes are active - if the computer fails on starship there's absolutely no hope, shuttle could at least passively glide and had parachutes, capsules passively orient themselves correctly, and obviously ablation is passive.  While it's nice to have fancy systems to minimise risk, you can't really beat a passive failsafe (something that automatically works when other systems are broken).

The problem with fly often and make it reliable, is that it really scales poorly. Lets say you do 100 successful flights in a row, what does that really show you? A potential problem that you didn't address is that if the upper stage of Starship needed to be used in an abort scenario, it would be full of fuel and very heavy. Even airplanes have to dump fuel if they have an emergency early in the flight. It would be a lot harder to dump fuel safely into rocket exhaust. The thrust/weight ratio would be much lower than typical reentry conditions and there might not be enough time to burn enough fuel to land safely.

Awesome long format deep dive! However, one important note about comparing probabilities and success rates: at 21:07 when you were ranking the most reliable rocket engines, it it tempting to just use the percentage of failures out of total missions (sample size) as a way of comparing engine reliability. However, it gets more complex when comparing different sample sizes.

For example, if engine A has flown a total of 100 times, and failed on 5 flights, we would say it has a 95% success rate. If engine B has only flown 10 times, and failed on 1 flight, we would say it has 99% success rate. So, we would be tempted to conclude that engine B is more reliable than engine A. However, this is not necessarily true, because of the different sample sizes.

To compare these two sample sizes correctly, we need to do some statistical analysis, and then determine if the differences we observe in engine success rates are statistically significant. And it might turn out that engine A is more reliable, statistically, than engine B, given engine A's larger sample size.

In any case, great video, I learned so much about abort systems and the balancing game of redundancy vs. simplicity. Keep it up!

There have been lots of technical surprises while underway ... not necessarily dangerous in their own right but always showing to our surprise how we were thinking inside the box after all ... and every unexpected failure coming from left field has a chance of resulting in a catastrophic unanticipated impact. I remember the first Shuttle in orbit could not shut the cargo bay door because thermal expansion in direct sunlight (bad surprise!). They finally were able to close the door by moving the shuttle cargo door into the shade.
There is a way to calculate how many more left field surprises remain undiscovered. When a new version of Fortran was released, many bugs would be discovered. The rate of discovering new bugs would drop off over time. This rate of discovery can be graphed. The area under the curve was the total number of bugs discovered. It was clear the bug discovery rate was dropping at a predictable rate. Thus you could extrapolate into the future the bug discovery rate with the area under the extrapolated curve being the number of yet undiscovered bugs. Likewise, we can get an idea of how many unanticipated rocket system failure modes are left. Whenever an updated version of Fortran was released, the bug discovery rate would jump up again but not as high as before.

There are known unknowns such as sigma deviation levels. The left field surprises are the unknown unknowns and from your mini-course in crew safety design, the outside-the-box surprises play a major role (e.g. 8 degree rotation of the earth setting off the emergency escape!)

There is one aspect you are not mentioning here. Starship has the largest crew capacity of any launcher with it's 100 passengers. Secondly it flies private citizens not astronauts and will largely be self guided with nobody on board trained to do any sort of manual abort. If I remember correctly the Soyuz has a maximum number of crew members of four or three and offers limited control to it's passengers in the event that something goes wrong that's not outright catastrophic. The way I see it these factors means that measured in sheer number of launches it doesn't make a whole lot of sense for SpaceX to have an escape system. However the PR fallout of having 100 people dying in your product means that if they can somehow abort, even if it takes the place of say 40 crew members in terms of weight, a system would have to be there. At least when they are ferrying private citizens to space. After all part of the reason why the relatively few shuttle accidents was such a big problem for NASA was because of the large crew of seven. The PR fallout of loosing so many people in one flight was pretty devastating. Especially for Columbia when news broke that the cause of the problem could have been found had NASA simply looked through their own footage from the launch as a similar accident had occurred in the past and the crew could have been saved by launching another orbiter or even Soyuz capsules to rendezvous with the damaged shuttle in orbit.


PS: The new and improved shuttle escape system of merely jumping out with a guide tube is pretty laughable. From what I have seen and heard in various documentaries nobody really thought that would be practical and work in a real emergency. NASA simply had to do something to appease the populace and perhaps more importantly the politicians.

Most science publication and programming falls in one of 2 extremes. 
Pop publications are dumbed down to the point that they give so little information that the reader gains no real working knowledge of the subject other than "scientists say". Readers can't even compare "What if's" 
The other extreme is publications for scientists. This has lots of beef to it, but it if you are not in the club, you can't speak the language. 

I am not a scientist & can't do most of the math, but I have been following and reading about space development for decades. So I am in the middle ground. The pop publications are useless to me and the industry publications are very challenging.

In a previous life I was one of the lead technicians at Boeing London Service Centre (the only one that was spelt that way). I quickly picked up the fact that the electronics doing BIT/BITE (Built In Test/Equipment) was actually the part that failed 90% of the time. Airlines would send failed kit in and it'd pass the automatic tests, except for when the test button was pressed. Dodgy capacitors that should be just injecting a test signal in were the issue. I loved working for Boeing, they wanted us to get to the root cause because they'd fix it. I'd hate for a similar system to suddenly decide that BOOM you're now launched into FKW*. The main operations are extensively tested and proven, but when things go wrong... not so much.

Regarding difficulty of air flight vs. space flight - the early transition of air flight from glorified wood and paper kites to aluminum stressed skins was similarly a major advance of materials science and engineering. But it is significant that the B17 was nearly cancelled due to the impossibility of successful flight, until the first element of systems engineering - the startup check list - was invented. The continued advance of safety and reliability due to precision methodology can not be understated. Space flight is the next order of magnitude of systems reliability management.

38:45 "So only about a half of a percent of flights would see any benefit"
That is not really the statistic that matters. If for example that half a percent would have been certain death and the launch abort would have saved 3/4 of those cases, then your launch abort system would still have made your entire architecture 4 times safer.
If your initial death rate was one in a million billion, then 4x safer is probably not significant compared to say your odds of dying due to natural causes during the flight anyway. When death rate is 1 in 200, 4 times better is pretty significant!

To your last question......."would you get on a rocket without an abort system?"  Could it be argued that we all get on airliners without abort systems?  Sure the FAA could require a parachute for every passenger but they dont.  In the early days of aviation maybe they did but after improving safety to the degree that it is, it's just not deemed neccessary.  I think eventually rockets will get there as well after much trial and error.

Early planes had passengers wear parachutes as an abort system. While I have done some skydiving (22 times) I don't think commercial airline service would be as successful as it is today if parachutes were still mandatory. In the long run Starship will need to gain airliner levels of reliability. But by flying many cargo flights first (e.g. F9 + Cargo Dragon), then with test pilot/trained astronauts knowing the risks (e.g. F9 + Crew Dragon), eventually after many flights and many years we may reach commercial passenger safety levels. One could conceive of carrying a CrewDragon, Starliner or DreamChaser as an escape-pod for some of those early missions, but it would severely limit the crew capacity and still be very limited in the flight envelope of when it could be used. Better to get it right for cargo flights first, then go with "the best part is no part". Few people thought a rocket could land. Now few people think you don't need an abort system.
No abort system on any airplanes anymore....they use to have parachutes. No commercial airline has parachutes for its passengers now.

Just one remark regarding the statistics: if we're talking about rocket reliability in general, you need to count all failures, not just crewed vehicles. Obviously you don't necessarily need an escape system on a cargo mission, but it still tells us a lot about the reliability of rockets if that mission fails and a LES could have saved the vehicle.

But I agree that in the long run rockets should (and will) just become reliable enough.

After Starship flies 100 times consecutively with no anomalies, I think even NASA will not complain. Even if SpaceX had to eat the cost of all of those launches, (i.e. no one volunteers to fly low-value payload[1] for reduced cost on any of those 100 flights), spending $200 million on testing is probably less than they would spend developing an abort system that would increase inert mass and complexity of every flight with questionable benefit. This reminds me of the electricity backup system in my former employer's building. It was one of the kind where you'd have to route the whole power through that backup system in order for it to be able to uninterruptedly take over power supply in case of a grid failure. The problem was that the probability of a failure inside the backup system itself was higher than the chances for a grid outage are in Germany. So by including the backup system into the power supply system, that would've actually increased the likelihood of a power outage in the building. That's why they decoupled the system and detached the backup system from power supply completely.

The best reason not to rely on launch abort is that they limit the number of people you launch at anyone time.

In the late-50s, early-60s the US started building supersonic bombers, most notably the XB-70 Valkyrie supersonic bomber. It would have a crew of IIRC 7. Research showed it was basically impossible to eject a crew in sequence at supersonic speeds fast enough to keep ahead of the of the craft disintegrating from just air pressure. The alternative was full cabin eject but that ran into the problem that the more mass you try to eject, the slower the separation from vehicle. The upper limit of full unit ejection is around 6-8 people max. Once beyond that point, physics requires so much power and acceleration it can't be done.

So, it you want a craft that can loft more than a half dozen people at a time, an escape system is right out. Either the entire craft works or it doesn't.

Yes, it needs an abort system. I would never risk myself, nor anyone I cared about, in a rocket without a launch escape system. Does it add complexity? Yes, but so does seat belts and airbags in cars... or lifeboats on ships.

It sounds great on paper to design a rocket with "airliner-like reliability", but that's like saying you are designing a car that never breaks down. It is impossible. Sooner or later, something breaks. And I highly doubt NASA would risk it either, at least not until it has done a LOT of flights and proven said reliability. And even then, you wouldn't want a system that will kill everyone unless every single part works every time forever.

If vehicles break down:
In a car: most of the time, you can simply stop and get it towed to be repaired.
In a plane: most of the time, you are still flying even though the engines fail. The wings will keep the plane gliding, at least maybe long enough to either do an emergency landing in a field or even restart the engines.
In a rocket: there is no time. Once the thrust fails for some reason, either it's the engines failing or the first stage exploding, you start falling. You can't glide. And considering the ridiculous amount of highly volatile fuel, it is very likely that any failure, like an engine exploding or a fuel line rupturing (or one of a thousand other catastrophic failure modes), will cause the entire rocket stack to at the very least take a lot of damage.

Even if "only" the first stage of the Superheavy/Starship stack fails, there is still no way of saving the crew. The upper stage has not enough thrust with full fuel to do any kind of safe landing back on Earth. And even if they manage to burn off enough fuel to get a positive thrust-to-weight and manage to slow down, where does it land? Depending on the time of failure, it may end up having to "land" in the ocean. And do we have any reason to believe that such a landing is even possible? And even if they somehow manage to put it down into the ocean at such a speed that it doesn't collapse, it will sink or tip over, both scenarios most likely killing everyone on board.

This is not hindsight, but foresight. If SpaceX insists on pushing forward with no launch escape system, and then one of their rockets explode with multiple people onboard, then nobody can say that they didn't see it coming. Anything can fail, and anything that CAN fail eventually will fail.

Hi reliability engineer here(although I work on robots). Some things to think about when looking at reliability are the difference between system and component reliability. Basically what component reliability is would be your 99.88% reliable engine but your system reliability takes into account all failures. With most systems they have components that are in series with eachother meaning if one thing fails the system fails(similar to series circuits vs parallel circuits) now you can stack components in series and in parallel. Your fuel tank would probably be a single thing so there is no redundancy but your engines are in parallel with one another so one can fail but your system will still work successfully. Now you can consider a more complex model for the engines since if you lose more than maybe 2-4 engines your rocket will stop flying up which is a failure, basically you enter that as a threshold of the failure of those redundant parts. In general anything in series can have it's reliability multiplied to the rest of the system to calculate the system reliability. Your subassembly with the parallel parts has a different equation to calculate that subassembly but then that can now be factored in like anything else in series.

Also what should be considered is what you consider a failure. Like you said in the video landing the rocket is not necessary for success so failures that only impact that won't be considered when determining primary success, but you could have a system reliability that is just for landing but that would include failures up until stage separation and down to landing and ignoring failures on the second stage and beyond.

Hopefully this is interesting to someone!

I do get the feeling that the AMOS-9 Falcon 9 RUD caused by the failed COPV is one of the reasons why Elon & SpaceX moved away from carbon fiber. As strong as carbon fiber is, it's fussy, expensive, and labor-intensive to make, and tiny errors during manufacturing (say an air bubble while laying down layers of carbon fiber & resin) can really damage its strength, or like what happened with AMOS-9, cause a delamination and a total failure. Steel isn't quite as strong for its weight, but the stainless SpaceX is using is resilient against extreme heat and cold, is much easier to work with during construction, it's cheap, its properties are well-known, and if the price there is you have to make your rocket a little bigger, well, that's the cheapest and most reliable option.

Thing is, when you're transporting up to 100 people into orbit just designing an abort system gets massively more complicated. I mean, assuming Starship's crew section weighs ~100 tonnes, and that an abort would require 4 g's of acceleration, you'd need an abort engine with ~5,000 kN of thrust, comparable to the F1 rocket engine! Then you need to pick a fuel, which is probably either nasty hypergolics (and a LOT of them at that) or solid fuels (which have their own safety issues), then you need to certify parachutes, heat shields, etc... Unless there's a version of Starship with only a small ~10 person crew capsule I don't see an abort mechanism being any safer than no abort mechanism.

With respect to the SpaceX "load and go" fueling procedure, remember that fueling before boarding the spacecraft has it's own hazards. If fueling is complete, then when the crew boards the spacecraft a large number of individuals (not JUST the astronauts) are strolling up to a vehicle with the destructive potential a small (very small) tactical nuke. It MIGHT well be that doing that is MORE dangerous than sitting there in the Starship, with an inherent limited abort capacity (as long as it is fueled first), while the booster is being fueled. Also, NASA was highly skeptical of the SpaceX way, but was persuaded after study, although this is in the context of Crew Dragon, which does have an abort system.


Also, is seems to me that Starship will be designed with greater margins to failure than anything else to this point. While it will obviously be a high performance vehicle, it does NOT need to be as close to the ragged edge as older hardware since is is intended to be refueled for missions that go beyond Earth orbit. Meaning that I would be surprised if structurally, it isn't considerably more robust (more margin in the tanks for example) in relative terms than existing hardware.

It only takes one crack for a previously 100% reliable system to become a failure statistic so yes, modern society will dictate an abort system will be needed..... But...

Statistics will also show that failures are so few and far between than they are probably not needed, like racing drivers, astronauts know and accept the risk that every time they sit in a rocket, it might be their last flight.

You made very good points, especially about heritage. However something to keep in mind is sometimes heritage isn't necessarily a good thing. Take a look at the Boeing 737 Max-8/9, a case of a design with a long and excellent heritage get pushed just that little bit too far. In the case of the 737 Max-8/9 the design considerations of the original 737 made a simple upgrade of the engines impossible whereas the Airbus A320 could simply hang the new engines on the wing. The 737 was made intentionally low to the ground to give it the ability to service airports that at the time generally lacked the loading equipment that is ubiquitous today. That lack of clearance compared to the much newer A320 family meant they hung the new engines in positions that would create natural pitching during operation, and they implemented a software system to keep the Max-8/9 the same classification to reduce the training required by law and to make it more appealing despite it's new flaws that were in most cases not even mentioned in the manual or Emergency handbook.

Analytical based decision on this is not valid - The need for a launch abort system is based on the number of unmanned flights (and how well instrumented) done prior to using the vehicle as a manned vehicle. Abort systems were added to early manned flights because they needed astronauts to operate, so it's first flight was manned.
With enough launches, there will be catastrophic failures, just as there are airliner catastrophic failures. keeping them few and far between will require early testing with lots of instrumentation to verify stress levels, then make sure the quality and design are sufficient to prevent them.

FACT 1: virtually NONE of the design details have been worked out for a human carrying Starship ... certainly abort systems could be included for a small crew ... but NOT for a 100 passenger Starship ... since a large abort mass can NOT be aborted away quick enough from a large exploding booster, inertia is a bitch!!!
FACT 2: if an actual paying customer emerges for a commercial passenger Starship .. that customer will define many of the design requirements, such as whether an abort system is required. The Starship is basically a demonstration of a 2 stage reusable launch vehicle ... it's possible that it will be safer for a human crew to go in a third stage that is customer specific.

21:44 Two comments here:

1) The in-flight RS-25 failure resulted in mission success, so if the standard is mission as you propose here, then...
2) It should be pointed out that the failure of the RS-25 here was caused by a short in either a sensor or the engine controller (I don't remember which). Either way, the engine shutdown was erroneous -- and, in fact, mission control recognized this and order the crew to disable the automatic system for the other two engines, which turned out to be the right call (within seconds of cutting out the automatic shutdown system the same problem requested a second engine shutdown).
The ironic thing is that Starship is a lot like one of the early Space shuttle concept of a hot body air/spacecraft with a titanium body and a lighter heat shield on the windward side.
